questions.question: How does Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) simplify privilege management in databases?

answers.a: By assigning permissions directly to every user individually.
answers.b: By grouping permissions into roles and assigning those roles to users.
answers.c: By allowing users to select their own permissions.
answers.d: By storing access rights in an external file system.

explanations.a: Incorrect. Assigning permissions individually increases complexity.
explanations.b: Correct. RBAC organizes permissions into roles for efficient management.
explanations.c: Incorrect. RBAC does not allow users to choose permissions.
explanations.d: Incorrect. RBAC operates at the database level, not the file system.

questions.question: Which scenario best demonstrates the use of RBAC?

answers.a: Every user has full access to all tables.
answers.b: Managers can update reports while interns can only view them.
answers.c: All users share one common login.
answers.d: All users have identical permissions regardless of job role.

explanations.a: Incorrect. Full access violates least privilege.
explanations.b: Correct. RBAC assigns permissions based on job roles.

questions.question: Which principle is enforced by RBAC to limit unnecessary access?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Normalization is unrelated to access control.
explanations.b: Correct. RBAC ensures users get only the permissions they need.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Access is restricted, not opened.

questions.question: How are access rights updated in RBAC when a user changes departments?

answers.a: The admin reassigns the user to a new role, updating permissions automatically.
answers.b: The user must request permissions one by one.
answers.c: All old permissions are retained permanently.
answers.d: The user must create a new account for the new role.

explanations.a: Correct. RBAC enables easy role reassignment.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Manual updates are not needed in RBAC.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Permissions depend on the current role.
explanations.d: Incorrect. A single account can be reassigned.

questions.question: What is a key advantage of RBAC for large organizations?

answers.a: It provides scalable control by assigning permissions through roles.
answers.b: It allows employees to change their own permissions freely.
answers.c: It works without any administrative configuration.

explanations.a: Correct. RBAC scales well with large user groups.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Admins define roles and mappings.
explanations.d: Incorrect. RBAC does not handle encryption.

questions.question: What is a security risk of an incorrectly configured RBAC system?

answers.a: Users may end up with more privileges than required.
answers.c: All roles will automatically balance their permissions.
answers.d: Users will lose access to the system permanently.

explanations.a: Correct. Misconfigured roles can lead to privilege escalation.
explanations.b: Incorrect. RBAC issues typically do not affect performance.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Role permissions must be defined manually.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Over-permission is more common than total lockout.
